motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI move that so much of standing and sessional orders be suspendedâ
âThe Leader of the Opposition does not have the call. I had in fact recognised the parliamentary secretary. The question is that the House do now adjourn. I call the honourable member for Makin.

âThe member for Makin will resume her seat. I did in fact recognise the parliamentary secretary. He proposed that the House do now adjourn. I put the question that the House do now adjourn. The member for Makin was first to her feet and has the call.

âI am only interrupting the Leader of the Opposition to enable him to be heard, not to interrupt him. But I point out to him that I thought he had risen on another matter, and for that reason when I put the question that the House do now adjourn I recognised the member for Makin. The Leader of the Opposition now has the call.

talker.name: Beazley, Kim, MP
Mr BEAZLEY
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition

talk.start.para: âI move dissent from your ruling, Mr Speaker.

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âNo, I have not. My ruling is consistent, and the Leader of the Opposition has moved dissent from it, as is his right.
âSo you have not actually called on the adjournment?

âFor the sake of clarificationâI do not know that this is entirely within the standing ordersâI recognised the parliamentary secretary, who moved that the House do now adjourn. The question before the House at this point in time is that the House do now adjourn. At that point I recognised the member for Makin because I believed the Leader of the Opposition was discussing another matter that I had not recognised. He has now moved dissent from my rulingâ
âAbsolutely.
âand that is the question before the House.
âThat is fine, Mr Speaker. I will move dissent from your ruling.
âIt is a dissent motion, old son.

âMr Speaker, my point of order is that the motion moved by the Leader of the Oppositionânamely, a dissent from your rulingâis unable to be moved by the Leader of the Opposition for the simple reason that you have not ruled.

âHear me out. My submission to you, Mr Speaker, is very simple and that is that it is not a ruling of the Speaker for the Speaker to call one side or the other. Mr Speaker, it is simply the practice of the House that you will call the person that you believe is seeking the call.
âThe Leader of the House has the call and will be heard in silence.

âMr Speaker, it is not a rulingâwhich can, therefore, be the subject of a motion of dissentâfor you to call somebody from this side. In fact, what the Leader of the Opposition is really attempting to do is toâ
âThe member for Prospect! The Leader of the House has the call.

âThe objection that the opposition have is to the fact that the Leader of the Opposition was not called. That is not a ruling on your part. The standing orders on this are quite clear. Standing order 61 states:

quote.para: When two or more Members rise together to speak the Speaker shall call upon the Member who, in the Speaker's opinion, first rose in his or her place; but it shall be in order to move that any Member who has risen âbe now heardâ or âdo now speakâ and the question shall be put forthwith and determined without amendment or debate.

interjection.para: So, Mr Speaker, it is simply a discretion for you to exercise. The reason that there was uncertaintyâif I may say so, quite understandablyâin your mind as to the intent of the Leader of the Opposition is that, his having put a proposition and your then having made it clear that you had given the call to the parliamentary secretary, the Leader of the Opposition remained at the dispatch box, and you were entitled to believe that he was remaining there for another purpose. On that basis, there cannot be a motion of dissent. You cannot receive it. The only motion, therefore, validly before the chair is the motion that the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
âI will, of course, recognise the Leader of the Opposition. I was waiting for the House to come to order.

âYou will recollect, Mr Speaker, that I asked you directly whether or not you had called on the adjournment or recognised the adjournment motion moved by the parliamentary secretary. You responded to me that you had, and I therefore moved dissent from your ruling. That was validly before you. It is longstanding custom in this place that when you have reported a matter to the House you respond to the person on their feet, and I was on my feet at this dispatch box.
âOrder! The Leader of the Opposition hasâ

âI am dissenting from the ruling, aren't I? I was on my feet at the dispatch box to seek your attention in order to discuss with you the matters on which you had reported. I was on my feet at the very moment you concluded those matters. Therefore, courtesy would have demanded that the call went to me at that point. When I asked you whether or not you had accepted the motion from the parliamentary secretary and you said you had, I moved dissent from your ruling that you accepted that motion. That is a deliberation that you have made; therefore it is a ruling that is quite capable of being dissented from. I am in the process of doing that, and the Leader of the House's intervention in that is entirely inappropriate.

âThe Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat, I presume, to allow me to reflect. There has been, as I hope all members would concur, a genuine effort from the chair to recognise people as appropriate. What I had overlooked, and this has been brought to my attention by the Leader of the House, was standing order 61. It is not possible for me to make a ruling in this instance but merely to give an opinion as to who was first on their feet. In this case, for reasons that the Leader of the Opposition understands, because I believed the matter he was addressing was not the question of the adjournment, I deemed that the member for Makin was on her feet and so ruled. Should the Leader of the Opposition wish to be heard at this stage, as he is aware, standing order 61 provides him with the opportunity to so move. But it is not in fact a case of moving dissent from my ruling, because I have in fact given an opinion about who was on their feet, not a ruling.

âMr Speaker, I was not moving dissent from the ruling of the member being on her feet; I was moving dissent from the ruling that you had made on the matter of calling the adjournment and that you had inappropriately called at that point. So I am moving dissent from that ruling, that ruling which I asked you whether or not you had made.
âMr Speakerâ

âI would remind a number of people in the chamber that the vast majority of them are not in fact in their normal seats, so the opportunity for them to participate in any way in the debate is somewhat restricted.
âOn page 280 of House of Representatives Practice under the subheading `Motion moved by a Minister' it states:

quote.para: The motion `That the House do now adjourn' can be moved only by a Minister (or Parliamentary Secretary) and no amendment can be moved to it.

interjection.para: Sir, I further draw your attention to a precedent cited on page 208 of the House of Representatives Practice:

quote.para: ... a member, during the adjournment debate, questioned the way in which Speaker Cameron had called Members during Question Time. The Speaker in reply said that the Member `will come to my office in due course, examine the figures, and next week he will state the correct position'.

interjection.para: In fact, anybody that goes on reading that will find that Speaker Cameron refused to give the call to that member for some lengthy period, and that of course is the precedent that has always been available to the Speaker in giving anybody the call. The Leader of the Opposition, whether he was standing on his feet or his head, only gets the call, Sir, if you choose to give it to him, and on this occasion you did not. That is not a ruling; that is, in fact, a discretion available to the chair. There are, therefore, no grounds on both cases for there to be any dissent ruling.

talk.start.para: âDon't talk stupid.
âMr Speaker, I am now dissenting from the ruling that you made in relation to the point of order that was raised by the Leader of the House.

motion.para: That the question be now put.

talk.start.para: âIt is not possible for the chair to accommodate a dissent motion at this stage, as standing order 61 clearly points out. It is inappropriate to enter into any debate.

subdebateinfo.title: South Vietnamese Government: Australian Defence Force Awards
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1014)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 October 1999:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the former Government of South Vietnam intended to present awards to some 21 Officers and Other Ranks of the 1st Australian Task Force in Vietnam following the battle of Long Tan, and that confirmation of this is available from Charles Tran Van Lam, former President of the Senate, Ambassador to Australia and Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Republic of South Vietnam.

(2) Is he able to say whether the then South Vietnamese Government had intended to present all soldiers and officers of D Coy, 6RAR, a unit citation in addition to awards to individual soldiers, but the presentation of the awards was prevented by the then Australian Government through the Ambassador to South Vietnam on the basis that Her Majesty, the Queen, had not given consent.
(3) Is he able to confirm that the Australian Government of the day gave a commitment that it would seek approval for these awards and allow them to be presented at a later date.
(4) Was the President of the then South Vietnam forced to substitute Vietnamese dolls and cigar boxes as presentations to these diggers in lieu of medals.

(5) Is it appropriate for these veterans to wear those trinkets in lieu of proper decorations on occasions such as Vietnam Veterans' Day or Anzac Day; if not, will he review the evidence from Mr Tran Van Lam and grant the retrospective approval for the correct awards.
(6) Why was this matter not dealt with under the review of the Vietnam End of War List completed earlier in 1999.

(7) Is he satisfied that the decorations presented to Australian Servicemen under the previous Imperial system of awards following the battle of Long Tan were the appropriate level of award; if so, on what basis does he make that assessment.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) This Issue was addressed by the Independent Review Panel on the End of War List-Vietnam. The Government of the Republic of Vietnam did intend to make awards to Australians involved in the Battle of Long Tan. Mr Tran Van Lam's views on this matter were made available to the Independent Review Panel.

(5) Veterans may display any form of awards recognising their service in any way they see appropriate, providing that if in government uniform, or in an official capacity representing the Government, it is accordance with relevant Instructions and protocols.
(6) The matter has been dealt with by the Independent Review Panel of the End of War List - Vietnam on page 33 of their report.

(7) Yes. Military commanders at each level in the field during Vietnam were well placed to assess the performance of individuals as nominations for awards were processed through the chain-of-command, rather than those physically far removed from the conflict at the time, or others in time some 33 years after the event.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 November 1999:

quote.para: (1) Are members of the Army Reserve who agree to undertake temporary continuous full-time service in Australia, East Timor or elsewhere, eligible to receive assistance under the ADF's Resettlement Scheme; if so, are they entitled to (a) resettlement information and advice, (b) discharge resettlement training, (c) approved absence for job-seeking and associated purposes and (d) financial assistance under the Services Vocational Educational Training Scheme for study in the member's own time.
(2) If reservists are ineligible for resettlement assistance, what measures are in place to facilitate their return to civilian life after a period of continuous full-time service.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) Members of the Army Reserve who undertake temporary continuous full-time service, be it in Australia, East Timor or elsewhere, transfer to the Permanent Force. Members of the Permanent Force do not have access to all of the Australian Defence Force's (ADF) resettlement assistance if their period of service in the Permanent Force is less than 12 years. Resettlement assistance becomes available to Permanent Force members progressively depending upon the length of service. Reserve Force members who do transfer will have access to resettlement information through unit level Resettlement Officers and ADF Resettlement Seminars.
(b) Members of the Reserve Force who transfer to the Permanent Force will not have access to Discharge Resettlement Training.
(c) Members of the Reserve Force who transfer to the Permanent Force will not have access to approved absences for job-seeking and associated purposes.
(d) Members of the Reserve Force who transfer to the Permanent Force will have access to the Services Vocational and Educational Training Scheme.

(2) It is not intended that resettlement assistance measures be developed specifically for Reserve Force members who transfer to the Permanent Force for short periods. These members, like other Permanent Force members who do not have a Reserve Force background, will not have been absent from the civilian environment and workforce for an extended period. Therefore, provision of such assistance is not necessary, as they are able to readily assimilate back into civilian life. To introduce such a specific provision for Reserve Force members would advantage these members ahead of Permanent Force personnel who have rendered similar short periods of service. Like all members, these members will have access to resettlement information through unit level Resettlement Officers and ADF Resettlement Seminars.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 23 November 1999:

quote.para: (1) Has naltrexone been approved in the USA for drug rehabilitation; if so, when was it approved.
(2) Which countries have approved naltrexone for use.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) ReVia, containing the active ingredient naltrexone, was first approved by the Food and Drug Administration, USA, on the 20 November 1984 for the treatment of opioid addiction and on the 30 December 1994 for the treatment of alcohol dependence.ReVia is not approved for ultra rapid opiate detoxification programs in the USA.

(2) Australia approved the use of naltrexone for treating opiate addiction and alcohol dependence in January 1999. Twenty-eight other countries have also approved naltrexone for these indications, including the U.S.A., France, Ireland, Luxembourg, Italy, Israel, Spain, Denmark, Netherlands, Oman, Austria, Pakistan, Brazil, Bahrain, Finland, Canada, Egypt, Colombia, Peru, Kuwait, Taiwan, Argentina, Bolivia, Eire, Hungary, Korea, Lithuania and Thailand.

13 countries had registered naltrexone for the treatment of opiate addiction only. These are U.K., Belgium, Germany, Poland, Singapore, Portugal, Switzerland, Malaysia, Greece, Saudi Arabia, Hong Kong, New Zealand, and U.A.E. Of these, Greece, New Zealand, Poland, Portugal and U.A.E. had marketing approvals pending for the treatment of alcohol dependence.

13 countries had marketing approvals pending for the treatment of opiate addiction and alcohol addiction. They are Chile, Ecuador, Estonia, Jordan, Latvia, Mexico, Norway, Paraguay, Uruguay, Russia, Slovenia, Sweden, and Venezuela.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 7 December 1999:

quote.para: (1) Will he provide details of the Government's agreement with the FIA, Australian Grand Prix Corporation and the previous Victorian Coalition Government in regard to the phasing out of tobacco sponsorship of the Formula One and 500cc Motorcycle Grands Prix.

(2) Is he able to say whether it is the current practice in the British, French and German Grand Prix races to allow logos only on cars and uniforms of drivers and pit crew and, in the case of the German Formula One Grand Prix, not to allow trackside signage; if so, will the Government implement restricted exemptions from the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act for the Australian Formula One Grand Prix to bring Australia into line with those races.

(3) Under policy announced in September 1998 to phase out all tobacco sponsorship of international sporting events held in Australia, will he provide details of the phase out schedule for the Australian Formula One Grand Prix with respect to matters such as trackside signage, brand names on cars and team uniforms and other advertising within the confines of the venue.

(4) Has he or his Department received reports on, or complaints of breaches of, the tobacco exemption granted for the 1999 Australian Formula One Grand Prix; if so, (a) will he release this information, (b) what action has been taken and (c) what steps will be taken in 2000 to ensure that the event complies with all conditions of the exemption.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government does not have any formal agreement with the Federation Internationale d'Automobile, the Australian Grand Prix Corporation or the previous Victorian Coalition Government in regard to the phasing out of tobacco sponsorship of the Formula One and Motorcycle Grands Prix. In my media release of 22 September 1998, I stated that my discussions and negotiations with Bernie Ecclestone and Max Mosely of the Federation Internationale d'Automobile were very productive and they had given me personal assurances that in view of the manner in which they had been involved in my deliberations and given the adequate lead times to arrange alternative sponsors, that automotive events would not be jeopardised by the phasing out of tobacco advertising.

(2) The Government is aware, in general terms, of the conditions set at the British, French and German Grand Prix races. I however, have consistently applied tighter restrictions on the extent of tobacco advertising at all events in Australia which have been granted an exemption than has been done by my predecessors. Further, given Australia's geographic isolation, I do not believe the examples you have given to be particularly relevant.

(3) The Government will lay the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act Amendment Bill before the House in the Autumn Parliamentary session. This Bill will ensure that as of 1 October 2006, there will be no tobacco sponsorship or advertising at any sporting or cultural event held in Australia. The Bill will allow for a transitional phase out period between 1 January 2002 and 1 October 2006, which will allow time for event organisers to work towards securing alternative sponsorship prior to the 2006 deadline. As stated in my media release of 22 September 1998, I believe that many events will choose to be totally tobacco free before the expiry of the phase out period.

(4) The Australian Grand Prix Corporation's compliance with the conditions imposed on tobacco advertising has been exemplary. Indeed, I have suggested to the organisers of some other events that have received section 18 exemptions that they should consult the Australian Grand Prix Corporation on the steps they have taken to ensure compliance by teams competing at their event. The Government received a number of complaints regarding tobacco advertising in and around Melbourne during the staging of the 1999 Formula One Grand Prix event. The majority of these complaints related to State legislation, rather than the conditions imposed by the Commonwealth. A member of the public contacted the Departmental officer monitoring the event on 5 March 1999 and claimed that health warning signs were not displayed at the entry to and exit from the Formula One exhibition. This complaint was investigated and found to be incorrect; health warning signs were displayed prominently at both the entry to and exit from the exhibition as required by the conditions imposed under the exemption. There was one complaint which was relevant to the terms and conditions imposed on the event.

(a) This complaint concerned the display of Winfield caps at one of the retail outlets within the Grand Prix circuit. The caps were displayed on Thursday 4 March 1999 by the proprietor of the particular outlet, despite clear instructions from the Australian Grand Prix Corporation on the application of the exemption.

(b) Immediate steps were taken to remedy the error and the caps were removed that day. A Departmental officer visited the Grand Prix site on Friday 5 March 1999 and noted that the caps were not on display. The Department advised the complainant that in light of the rapid remedial action, it was unlikely that any further action would be taken.

(c)As with previous events, Departmental officers will attend the event to monitor compliance with the terms and conditions imposed on the event. Event organisers have been advised that non-compliance with the terms of the exemption will be taken into account when considering future applications for exemption, and that non-compliance could lead to prosecution.

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1180)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torees Strait Islander Affairs, upon noice, on 16 February 2000:

quote.para: (1) What will be the total cost to the Indigenous Land Corporation (ILC) for compliance with the Government's Goods and Services Tax.
(2) What sum has been, or will be, spent in each budget year on GST compliance costs by ILC.
(3) From which programs will the cost of this GST compliance be found.
(4) Will the Government be providing extra funding to ILC to cover these GST compliance costs.

(5) Has ILC estimated the cost to ILC funded Indigenous corporations or other entities of compliance with the GST; if so, what is the total of this compliance cost for Indigenous corporations and entities, and what is the average cost for each corporation or entity.

(6) Has ILC estimated the cost to any non-ILC funded Indigenous corporations, bodies or entities of compliance with the GST; if so, what are the names of these organisations and what are their individual estimated GST compliance costs.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following information to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) It is estimated that the total cost to the ILC for compliance with the Government's Goods and Services Tax is in the vicinity of $100,000. This takes into account the use of external consultants, the allocation of key staff time for the implementation process and the cost of training sessions to be conducted with all staff. This estimate does not include resources that may be allocated to provide advice or logistical support to Indigenous groups on GST matters.

(2) Ongoing compliance costs to the ILC for each budget year are expected to be approximately $40,000. This amount includes allocation of resources for ongoing compliance and lodging of returns, ongoing staff training, supervision of GST resources that may be allocated to provide advice or logistical support to Indigenous group on GST matters.

(3) The ILC receives and annual allocation from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Fund Reserve according to a formula set out in the ATSIC Act. The ILC utilises this allocation to perform its two statutory functions being to assist Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to acquire and to manage indigenous-held land. The ILC utilises the earnings on the unused allocation to subsidise its administration costs. Administration costs in excess of investment earnings are met from the balance of the allocation from the Land Fund. The cost of GST compliance will be met in the same manner as administration costs are currently met.
(4) As a result of the way that the ILC is funded there will be no extra funding to the ILC to cover compliance costs.

(5) The ILC's Land Management program does not operate on an annual funding cycle. Each proposal is assessed by the ILC on its merits. Each funding package is designed specifically for each project. Therefore the components of each package will need to be reviewed for GST implications on the assessment of the proposal. Compliance costs to the Indigenous corporations and other entities will depend not only on the nature of assistance from the ILC, but also on that of other sources of assistance, the complexity of their operations and the corporation's or other entity's status for GST. An estimate of the total cost of compliance for Indigenous corporations or other entities has not been undertaken by the ILC at this time. The ILC is in the process of engaging external GST experts with a brief to address ILC's GST related issues and their impact on the Indigenous corporations and other entities. These consultants have already conducted considerable work in this area for other Indigenous agencies.
(6) The ILC has not estimated the cost to any non-ILC funded Indigenous corporations, bodies or entities of compliance with the GST.

(7) No. However, the ILC is currently undertaking a GST implementation plan which has identified a number of issues on which the ILC requires clarification as to the full impact of the GST and is seeking external advice on these matters.

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1196)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 17 February 2000:

(2) What cost benefit outcomes were forecast in the study identified in part (1).
(3) How many of the 7000 jobs expected to be generated in regional Australia will be generated (a) in the construction phase and (b) on an ongoing basis.
(4) What estimates does the Government have for the potential of the project to improve Australia's export opportunities.

(5) Is it a fact that if the project has a $480 million public investment in it, then the average public cost per job is $69,000; if so, how does the average cost compare with alternative job generating projects in regional Australia, including through improved public investment in education.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The Commonwealth's decision to contribute funds to the project was not based on any one particular feasibility study but on the significant benefits that the rail link will provide to the Northern Territory, South Australia and the entire nation.
(3) The Commonwealth has not conducted a detailed analysis of the likely breakdown of the employment that will be generated by the rail link.
The AustralAsia Railway Corporation 1998-99 Annual Report forecasts that the project will increase national employment by 7100 jobs in 2001-02.

(4) The Commonwealth has not conducted in depth forecasting of the export opportunities that will be created by the project. However, it is expected the rail link will facilitate the growth of export based industries.

(5) While a large number of jobs will be created during the construction and operation of the railway, it is not appropriate to compare the cost of each job associated with the railway with that for other projects. subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Radio Broadcasting Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1219)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 7 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is the Government committed to providing regional and remote area radio listeners who have print handicap with the same level of broadcasting service provided to those in metropolitan areas; if so, how.
(2) Has the Minister investigated the pricing proposal from Radio for all Australians Association Inc. to broadcast from one fully equipped studio by satellite.
(3) When will the Government make a final decision on funding for the proposal.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) has been progressively planning new radio services throughout Australia and new radio licences have already been allocated in most regional and remote areas. Four regional community licences have been granted to RPH Australia, the national body that represents radio for the print handicapped service providers. In addition, RPH Australia has established a satellite service that carries dedicated programming for the print handicapped and can be accessed and rebroadcast by community radio stations, or picked up by direct to home satellite receivers.

(2) The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts and the ABA have investigated the proposal put forward by Radio for all Australians Association Inc. In addition to the cost of establishing a satellite service, a national network would require the installation of terrestrial transmitters and access to broadcasting band frequencies. Unfortunately, the shortage of suitable frequencies is a major obstacle to establishing a national network. In most regional licence areas, the ABA has allocated all available frequencies for new licences. As indicated previously, RPH Australia already has in place a national satellite service with programming dedicated to the print handicapped.

(3) Funding to implement proposals of this nature would be considered in the Budget context. The Government already provides funding to the Community Broadcasting Foundation Ltd for services for the print handicapped. In 1999-2000, $270,000 was allocated to RPH stations, and an additional $358,000 was provided for transmission of those services.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Properties: Recommendation for Sale
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1230)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 8 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Which CSIRO properties have been recommended for sale as a result of the recent CSIRO property review.
(2) What is the current estimated book value of each property recommended for sale.
(3) What is the current estimated annual rent level likely to be required for each property recommended for sale.
(4) What is the current estimated annual rent expressed as a percentage of the current estimated book value for each property recommended for sale.

(5) If the property sales go ahead will funds previously marked for research be used to pay property leases and rents; if so, will the Commonwealth adequately compensate the CSIRO budget if any CSIRO property sales do have a negative effect on the CSIRO's overall financial position and available research funds.
(6) What benefits to the Commonwealth will result from the sale of CSIRO.

talker.name: Fahey, John, MP
Mr Fahey
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1), (2), (3), (4). The CSIRO Property Review Committee has reported to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources and me. The Government is currently considering this report therefore no properties have been recommended for sale.

(5) The Government continues to value the capacity of CSIRO to contribute to the future wealth of the nation. CSIRO is provided with appropriation funding to undertake its statutory functions. The appropriation funds for the coming three years were announced in last year's Budget.

(6) The sale of CSIRO is not proposed. The Government's policy is to ensure that it makes better use of scarce capital than by engaging in property investment. The sale of Commonwealth property puts the Commonwealth on a firmer financial footing, allowing it to retire debt, invest in programs to enhance productivity, or to provide additional funding for its priorities without the need to raise taxes.
